elements.content: Two novel coordination polymers with formulas CoL1·3H2O [1, L1 = 3,3′-((1,7-dioxa-4,10-diazacyclododecane-4,10-diyl)­bis(methylene) dibenzenecarboxylate] and Co2 L2(H2O)2·2(H2O) [2, L2 = 5,5′-((1,7-dioxa-4,10-diazacyclododecane-4,10-diyl)­bis(methylene)) diisophthalate] were synthesized, where one Co(II) ion coordinates the crown-4 moiety of the ligand. Compound 1 crystallizes in the space group C2 as an infinite two-dimensional chiral layered coordination network with a tetragonal 44 sql net topology. The structural unit consists of the coordinated Co(II) ion and the deprotonated ligand. The Co(II) ion is 6-coordinate with two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms of the crown 1,7-diaza-12-crown-4, and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from neighboring ligands, and exhibits a highly distorted octahedral geometry. Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n as a triply interpenetrating 3D network with the uncommon sqc528/dmd system, the first coordination polymer with a 3-fold interpenetrating dmd topology. It exhibits two distinct Co(II) ions. One is in the center of the crown-4 along with two cis-coordinated water molecules in a highly distorted octahedral geometry; the other is 4-coordinate with tetrahedral geometry and a node in the framework. Weak antiferromagnetic interactions exist between the cobalt centers in both compounds.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs), including metal organic frameworks (MOFs), are of great interest for applications in heterogeneous catalysis, gas adsorption, storage, separation, magnetism, and optical sensors in addition to their very intriguing topologies. Their structures are based on extended networks of coordinately bonded metal ions/clusters and multidentate organic linkers. The metal ions typically serve as coordination nodes. The metal centers are usually saturated from full coordination and are, therefore, generally inaccessible due to steric hindrance. However, positioning of the metal ions close to the center of the organic linkers (yielding a metalloligand) can potentially lead to materials with new architectures and may also yield metal sites that are in more accessible locations. Accessibility is essential in order for the materials to be useful for applications such as adsorption and catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs), including metal organic frameworks (MOFs), are of great interest for applications in heterogeneous catalysis, gas adsorption, storage, separation, magnetism, and optical sensors in addition to their very intriguing topologies. Their structures are based on extended networks of coordinately bonded metal ions/clusters and multidentate organic linkers. The metal ions typically serve as coordination nodes. The metal centers are usually saturated from full coordination and are, therefore, generally inaccessible due to steric hindrance. However, positioning of the metal ions close to the center of the organic linkers (yielding a metalloligand) can potentially lead to materials with new architectures and may also yield metal sites that are in more accessible locations. Accessibility is essential in order for the materials to be useful for applications such as adsorption and catalysis.

elements.content: The use of metalloligand-based linkers to synthesize CPs and MOFs has been reported only by a few researchers, examples of which include Ag-tris(dipyrrinato), Mn metalloporphyrins, Cu-pyridine-2,4-dicarboxylate, Fe, Ru, Os porphyrinato and phthalocyaninato macrocycles, 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate–Mn(II) chiral Schiff base metalloligand, Pt2+ bypyridyl carboxylate, and Pd organometallic complexes. A macrocyclic polyamine tetraacetic acid was recently used to synthesize heterometallic MOFs. In this case, two of the four acetate groups are not available for extended network connectivity since they are locked in chelation of the zinc metal ion that is within the center of the polyamine macrocycle. N,N′-Bis(4-pyridyl-methyl)diaza-18-crown-6 was used to synthesize 1D and 2D coordination polymers in which the 4-pyridyl portion of the ligand coordinated with Co2+, Fe2+, and Ag+ metal ions. The additional incorporation of K+, Ba2+, Ca2+, and Ag+ in the crown moiety afforded adjustment in the extension and conformation of the ligand, leading to variations in the architectures obtained.

N,N'-Bis(4-pyridyl-methyl)diaza-18-crown-6 was used to synthesize 1D and 2D coordination polymers in which the 4-pyridyl portion of the ligand coordinated with Co2+, Fe2+, and Ag+ metal ions. elements.content: We herein investigated the design and the use of novel chelating N,N′-bis(methylene) dibenzoate or diisophthalate functionalized diaza-12-crown platforms to coordinate the metal within their crown moiety while simultaneously directing the self-assembly of the final CP structures. The ligands are designed with the crown moiety of an appropriate size required to accommodate first row transition-metal ions, and with the two nitrogen and two oxygen atoms of the crown-4 moiety providing coordination sites. The methyl benzene component of the ligand was incorporated as a spacer to avoid intraligand coordination of the carboxylate with its crown-encapsulated metal centers. The spacer, however, introduced flexibility around the methylene group, which added another variable that could affect the resulting topologies. It is reported that, in general, flexible ligands tend to favor the formation of 1D and 2D networks; 3D structures are also formed, but are less favored.
elements.clean_text: We herein investigated the design and the use of novel chelating N,N'-bis(methylene) dibenzoate or diisophthalate functionalized diaza-12-crown platforms to coordinate the metal within their crown moiety while simultaneously directing the self-assembly of the final CP structures. The ligands are designed with the crown moiety of an appropriate size required to accommodate first row transition-metal ions, and with the two nitrogen and two oxygen atoms of the crown-4 moiety providing coordination sites. The methyl benzene component of the ligand was incorporated as a spacer to avoid intraligand coordination of the carboxylate with its crown-encapsulated metal centers. The spacer, however, introduced flexibility around the methylene group, which added another variable that could affect the resulting topologies. It is reported that, in general, flexible ligands tend to favor the formation of 1D and 2D networks; 3D structures are also formed, but are less favored.

elements.content: We present herein two novel cobalt-containing CPs, compounds 1 and 2, which are characterized by the in situ encapsulation of single cobalt centers within the crown-4 moiety of macrocyclic carboxylate organic ligands. Compound 1 is a 2D layered structure formed from the reaction of Co(II) ions with 3,3′-((1,7-dioxa-4,10-diazacyclododecane-4,10-diyl)­bis(methylene))dibenzoic acid (L1H 2 ). Compound 2 in a 3D triply interpenetration network, formed from the reaction of Co(II) ions with the tetracarboxylic acid, (5,5′-((1,7-dioxa-4,10-diazacyclododecane-4,10-diyl)­bis(methylene))diisophthalic acid, (L2H 4 ) (L2 = N,N′-bis[(3,5-benzenedicarboxy)-methyl]-1,7-diaza-12-crown-4). Their structures were characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), and magnetic susceptibility measurements.

Compound 2 in a 3D triply interpenetration network, formed from the reaction of Co(II) ions with the tetracarboxylic acid, (5,5'-((1,7-dioxa-4,10-diazacyclododecane-4,10-diyl)bis(methylene))diisophthalic acid, (L2H  4 ) (L2 = N,N'-bis[(3,5-benzenedicarboxy)-methyl]-1,7-diaza-12-crown-4). Their structures were characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), and magnetic susceptibility measurements.

elements.content: 1H and 13C NMR spectra were acquired on a Bruker AVANCE400 spectrometer at 400 and 100 MHz, respectively (peak pattern: d, doublet; m, multilet; q, quartet; s, singlet; t, triplet). Infrared measurements were recorded on a Bruker Alpha-P FTIR spectrophotometer (intensive pattern: m, medium; s, strong; w, weak). Single-crystal X-ray data were collected on a Bruker APEX2 diffractometer with 1.6 kW graphite monochromated Mo radiation. The frames were integrated with SAINT v7.68a (Bruker, 2009). The structure was solved and refined with Olex2 and SHELX (Sheldrick, 2008). Elemental analysis was conducted by Atlantic Microlab (Norcross, GA). Thermogravimetric analysis was conducted on a TA Instrument Q50 thermal analyzer. Aliquots of 5 mg were heated at a rate of 5 °C/min from ambient temperature to 700 °C under air flow. Temperature-dependent magnetization measurements were carried out on a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer (Quantum Design MPMS-5S). All samples for the magnetic measurements were prepared by fully dispersing an appropriate amount of dry powder nanocrystals in eicosane.

Characterization

 1H and 13C NMR spectra were acquired on a Bruker AVANCE400 spectrometer at 400 and 100 MHz, respectively (peak pattern: d, doublet; m, multilet; q, quartet; s, singlet; t, triplet). Infrared measurements were recorded on a Bruker Alpha-P FTIR spectrophotometer (intensive pattern: m, medium; s, strong; w, weak). Single-crystal X-ray data were collected on a Bruker APEX2 diffractometer with 1.6 kW graphite monochromated Mo radiation. The frames were integrated with SAINT v7.68a (Bruker, 2009). The structure was solved and refined with Olex2 and SHELX (Sheldrick, 2008). Elemental analysis was conducted by Atlantic Microlab (Norcross, GA). Thermogravimetric analysis was conducted on a TA Instrument Q50 thermal analyzer. Aliquots of 5 mg were heated at a rate of 5 °C/min from ambient temperature to 700 °C under air flow. Temperature-dependent magnetization measurements were carried out on a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer (Quantum Design MPMS-5S). All samples for the magnetic measurements were prepared by fully dispersing an appropriate amount of dry powder nanocrystals in eicosane.

elements.content: Compound 1 is stable in air and is insoluble in common organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, THF, and DMF. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2 and is an infinite two-dimensional (2D) chiral layered coordination network. Crystal data are presented in Table , and bond angles, bond lengths, and other crystallographic details are presented in Tables S1–S6 (). The structural unit consists of one coordinated Co(II) ion and the deprotonated ligand, L1. Three interlayer water molecules are present. The Co(II) ion is 6-coordinate with two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms of the crown 1,7-diaza-12-crown-4, and two carboxyl oxygen atoms from each of two neighboring ligands (Figures and ), and exhibits a highly distorted octahedral geometry. The bond lengths of Co1–O1, Co1–O2, and Co1–N1 are 2.2405(19), 2.020(2), and 2.235(2) Å, respectively. The angles of O1–Co1–O1 and O2–Co1–O2 are 114.5(1)° and 91.1(1)°, respectively. The shortest distance between two neighbor Co(II) ions within a chain is 9.225 Å (Figure ). The dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 62.5(3)°.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of Coordination Polymer 1 

Compound 1 is stable in air and is insoluble in common organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, THF, and DMF. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2 and is an infinite two-dimensional (2D) chiral layered coordination network. Crystal data are presented in Table , and bond angles, bond lengths, and other crystallographic details are presented in Tables S1-S6 (). The structural unit consists of one coordinated Co(II) ion and the deprotonated ligand, L1. Three interlayer water molecules are present. The Co(II) ion is 6-coordinate with two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms of the crown 1,7-diaza-12-crown-4, and two carboxyl oxygen atoms from each of two neighboring ligands (Figures  and ), and exhibits a highly distorted octahedral geometry. The bond lengths of Co1-O1, Co1-O2, and Co1-N1 are 2.2405(19), 2.020(2), and 2.235(2) Å, respectively. The angles of O1-Co1-O1 and O2-Co1-O2 are 114.5(1)° and 91.1(1)°, respectively. The shortest distance between two neighbor Co(II) ions within a chain is 9.225 Å (Figure ). The dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 62.5(3)°.

elements.content: The 2D layers contain bond circuits that are composed of 32-membered metallomacrocycle rings. Each is composed of the non-hydrogen atoms from one full and two half ligands, along with four Co(II) ions. The Co···Co distances across the length and breadth of the macrocycle are 16.724 and 8.366 Å, respectively. The Co(II) atoms form the nodes of the two-dimensional network (Figures and ). The ligands are locked in a fixed configuration on coordination with the Co(II) metal ions. Chirality is imposed in the structure as a result (Figures and ). The interlayer water molecules participate in hydrogen bonding (Figure ).

elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of Coordination Polymer 2 

Compound 2 is stable in air and is insoluble in common organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, THF, and DMF. An X-ray data set was collected on a crystal with dimensions of 0.33 × 0.29 × 0.26 mm3. Crystal data are presented in Table , and bond angles, bond lengths, and other crystallographic details are shown in Tables S7-S12 (). X-ray crystallography identifies the formula of 2 as [Co2(C26H30N2O12)(H2O)2]⋅2(H2O). The structure crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and is a triply interpenetrating three-dimensional (3D) network. The asymmetric unit consists of the deprotonated octadentate ligand, L2, and two distinct cobalt atoms (Figures  and ). Each ligand coordinates to five cobalt atoms: one through the crown moiety and the four others via the carboxyl groups (Figure ). The cobalt (Co1) atom in the center of the crown is 6-coordinate: two nitrogen and two oxygen atoms from the crown and two cis-coordinated water molecules.

elements.content: Unique coordination geometry of the ligand unit L2, showing tetradentate coordination by the crown and monodentate coordination of the four carboxyl groups in 2.
elements.clean_text: 7  Unique coordination geometry of the ligand unit L2, showing tetradentate coordination by the crown and monodentate coordination of the four carboxyl groups in 2.

elements.content: A portion of the infinite 3D network showing the two different Co coordination environments in 2.
elements.clean_text: 8  A portion of the infinite 3D network showing the two different Co coordination environments in 2.

elements.content: The four ligating atoms of the crown distort the octahedral geometry. The distortion has the effect of moving the Co atom out of the center of the polyhedron with the Co atom projecting out of the plane of the macrocyclic ring, and an octahedral edge (the line joining O1 and O2) closer to the metal atom. The distortion is large; the angles about the central Co atom are in the range of 77.7–104.0°. The other crystallographically unique cobalt atom (Co2) is 4-coordinate with a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Figure ) and angles in the range of 88–124°. Two bridging methylene groups (C18) of the 1,7-diaza-12-crown-4 molecule are disordered. The disorder is a result of a conformational switch of the methylene groups around the coordinating O and N atoms and is modeled using two disorder components. Each bridging methylene group (C18) between the benzene ring and the crown shows a C–C–N angle of 114°, which ensures significant curvature to the zigzag repeating unit.
elements.clean_text: The four ligating atoms of the crown distort the octahedral geometry. The distortion has the effect of moving the Co atom out of the center of the polyhedron with the Co atom projecting out of the plane of the macrocyclic ring, and an octahedral edge (the line joining O1 and O2) closer to the metal atom. The distortion is large; the angles about the central Co atom are in the range of 77.7-104.0°. The other crystallographically unique cobalt atom (Co2) is 4-coordinate with a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Figure ) and angles in the range of 88-124°. Two bridging methylene groups (C18) of the 1,7-diaza-12-crown-4 molecule are disordered. The disorder is a result of a conformational switch of the methylene groups around the coordinating O and N atoms and is modeled using two disorder components. Each bridging methylene group (C18) between the benzene ring and the crown shows a C-C-N angle of 114°, which ensures significant curvature to the zigzag repeating unit.

elements.content: Each net in the 3D structure contains bond circuits that are composed of 16-membered metallomacrocycle rings (Figure ). Each is composed of the non-hydrogen atoms from two half ligands, along with two Co2 atoms. The Co···Co distance is 7.406 Å. The Co2 atoms form the nodes of the 3D network (Figures and ).

Each is composed of the non-hydrogen atoms from two half ligands, along with two Co2 atoms. The Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance is 7.406 Å. The Co2 atoms form the nodes of the 3D network (Figures  and ).

elements.content: A portion of one of the three 3D networks that make up the crystal structure in 2. The C–C–N angle of approximately 114° gives stepped and curved linkage units (red = oxygen, light blue = cobalt, dark blue = nitrogen, and gray = carbon).
elements.clean_text: 9  A portion of one of the three 3D networks that make up the crystal structure in 2. The C-C-N angle of approximately 114° gives stepped and curved linkage units (red = oxygen, light blue = cobalt, dark blue = nitrogen, and gray = carbon).

elements.content: Structure 2 is a 3D network that is composed of three interpenetrating nets (Figures and ) that superimpose by translating them along the b axis; the interpenetration vector is [010]. Extensive internet hydrogen bonding exists between the ligands’ carboxylate groups, the coordinated water molecules, and two occluded noncoordinated water molecules (Table S12, ). To derive the net symbol, the network was simplified where the centers of the benzene-1,3-dicarboxylate groups are 3-coordinated nodes in the structure and the tetrahedral Co2 atoms are considered 4-coordinate nodes (Figures – ). The structure is characterized as a 2-nodal 3,4-c net with stoichiometry (3-c)2­(4-c) and dmd, sqc528 topology. The point symbol for each net is (4.102)2­(42.104). The interpenetration is of Class Ia, and the structure is, to the best of our knowledge, the first example of 3-fold dmd topology in coordination networks.
elements.clean_text: Structure 2 is a 3D network that is composed of three interpenetrating nets (Figures  and ) that superimpose by translating them along the b axis; the interpenetration vector is [010]. Extensive internet hydrogen bonding exists between the ligands' carboxylate groups, the coordinated water molecules, and two occluded noncoordinated water molecules (Table S12, ). To derive the net symbol, the network was simplified where the centers of the benzene-1,3-dicarboxylate groups are 3-coordinated nodes in the structure and the tetrahedral Co2 atoms are considered 4-coordinate nodes (Figures -   ). The structure is characterized as a 2-nodal 3,4-c net with stoichiometry (3-c)2(4-c) and dmd, sqc528 topology. The point symbol for each net is (4.102)2(42.104). The interpenetration is of Class Ia, and the structure is, to the best of our knowledge, the first example of 3-fold dmd topology in coordination networks.

Ligand L1H 2 exhibits CH2–O–CH2 and CH2–N–CH2 stretching bands at 1126 and 1136 cm–1, respectively; when in compound 1, these bands shift to 1086 and 1074 cm–1, respectively, due to the reducing bond strength of C–O and C–N when Co(II) coordinates with nitrogen and oxygen atoms of crown moieties of the deprotonated ligand L1.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectral Analysis

Compound 1 

The CO stretching and C-O stretching bands of ligand L1 are observed at 1711 and 1291 cm-1, respectively; the bands are split into 1622 and 1611 cm-1 (νa (CO2)) and 1369 and 1346 cm-1 (νs (CO2)) for the compound 1 due to formation of the bonds between Co(II) and (CO2)1- (Figure S1a, ). Ligand L1H  2  exhibits CH2-O-CH2 and CH2-N-CH2 stretching bands at 1126 and 1136 cm-1, respectively; when in compound 1, these bands shift to 1086 and 1074 cm-1, respectively, due to the reducing bond strength of C-O and C-N when Co(II) coordinates with nitrogen and oxygen atoms of crown moieties of the deprotonated ligand L1.

elements.content: Infrared spectral analysis shows changes in the vibrational frequencies of the functional groups in the free ligand L2H 4 and compound 2 (Figure S1b, ). The strong absorbance at 1662 cm–1 is assigned to ν (CO) of COOH in L2H 4 and absorbances of 1602 and 1411 are due to νa(CO2)2···NRR′R″ and νs(CO2)2–.NRR′R″, respectively. A much stronger absorbance at 1662 cm–1 than at 1602 and 1411 cm–1 indicates that the COOH conformation is dominant in the ligand. The peak at 1662 cm–1 disappears for compound 2 due to the formation of (CO2)Co and shows that the ligand was deprotonated. The absorbance at 1602 cm–1 of νa(CO2)2 in the ligand splits into two peaks at 1613 and 1566 cm–1, and the absorbance at 1411 cm–1 of νs(CO2)2– into two peaks at 1372 and 1342 cm–1 for compound 2, respectively, ascribed to the transformation of COOH of the former into carboxylate COO1– in the latter. The absorbance of 1239 cm–1 (w, ν (C–N–C)) and 1130 cm–1 (m, ν (C–O–C)) in the ligand are red shifted to 1226 and 1092 cm–1 in 2, respectively, as the coordination bonds, Co–O and Co–N, distribute electrons of the oxygen and nitrogen atoms and reduce the vibration frequencies of ν(C–N–C) and of ν(C–O–C). The IR data confirmed the presence of the 1,3,5-trisubstituted benzene ring in both ligand and 2 according to the following assignments: the absorbances at 1463 cm–1 (νCC)), 1446 cm–1 (ν(CC)), 911 cm–1 (γ(C–H), and 881 cm–1 (σ(ring) for the former, and the absorbance at 1488 (ν(CC)), 1449 cm–1 (ν(CC)), 913 cm–1 (γ(C–H)), and 715 cm–1 (σ(ring)) for the latter.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of 1 in air shows a weight loss event of 3.48% from room temperature to 374 °C, corresponding to one molecule of water (Figure a). This was followed by a second weight loss event of 81.3% between 374 and 417 °C, corresponding to degradation of the ligand (expected 82.5%). The residue of 16.7% beyond 417 °C is assigned to the cobalt oxide residue.

Thermal Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis of 1 in air shows a weight loss event of 3.48% from room temperature to 374 °C, corresponding to one molecule of water (Figure a). This was followed by a second weight loss event of 81.3% between 374 and 417 °C, corresponding to degradation of the ligand (expected 82.5%). The residue of 16.7% beyond 417 °C is assigned to the cobalt oxide residue.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis curve of 2 shows a gradual weight loss of 4.90% up to 210 °C (Figure b), which corresponds to the removal of two uncoordinated water molecules per unit formula (calculated 4.8 wt %). The structure remained stable up to 320 °C, at which two rapid and close weight loss events occurred. The first was 9.6 wt %, corresponding to the loss of two coordinated water molecules. The second weight loss of 71.2% corresponded to the decomposition of the structure (calculated 68.4 wt %). The remaining 21.9 wt % is assigned to the cobalt oxide residue (calculated 19.9 wt %).

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 1 were investigated in the range of 5–300 K. Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were measured down to 5 K, and χM T values versus temperature are plotted in Figure a, where χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility per molecular unit. The temperature-dependent susceptibility curve shows that the χM T value decreases gradually with temperature, from ∼5.1 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K to 3.5 cm3 mol–1 K at 25 K, and can be considered obeying the Curie–Weiss law with the Curie constant, C, of about 4 cm3 mol–1 K. The small, but abrupt, decrease of χM T below 24 K is attributed to weak antiferromagnetic coupling between cobalt centers.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Susceptibility

The magnetic properties of 1 were investigated in the range of 5-300 K. Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were measured down to 5 K, and χM T values versus temperature are plotted in Figure a, where χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility per molecular unit. The temperature-dependent susceptibility curve shows that the χM T value decreases gradually with temperature, from ~5.1 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K to 3.5 cm3 mol-1 K at 25 K, and can be considered obeying the Curie-Weiss law with the Curie constant, C, of about 4 cm3 mol-1 K. The small, but abrupt, decrease of χM T below 24 K is attributed to weak antiferromagnetic coupling between cobalt centers.

elements.content: (a) Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility plot for 1. (b) Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility plot for 2.
elements.clean_text: 15  (a) Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility plot for 1. (b) Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility plot for 2.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 2 were also investigated in the range of 5–300 K. The temperature-dependent susceptibility curve shows that the χM T value decreases gradually with temperature, from 15.1 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K to 6.0 cm3 mol–1 K at 120 K (Figure b). The graph profile is similar to that of compound 1. It is typical of independent paramagnetic cobalt ions. The abrupt decrease of χM T below 10 K is attributed to weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The high value of χM T at room temperature is larger than the expected spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 mol–1 K for two noninteracting Co(II) with spin S = 3/2 and is attributed to spin–orbit coupling. The temperature-dependent change in Curie constant, especially for compound 2, suggests some possible electron transition on metal centers with changing temperature. Surely, it is fundamentally very interesting, and detailed studies should be further conducted.

elements.content: Two novel cobalt coordination polymers 1 and 2 are synthesized based on the use of newly designed ligands L1H 2 and L2H 4 , both containing the diaza-12-crown moiety. In both cases, Co(II) ions are coordinated toward the crown-4 moiety and are, therefore, positioned within the center of the ligand. The ligand L1H 2 with two carboxylate groups produces a 2D layered chiral structure of tetragonal sql net topology and with the Co(II) ions serving as the coordination nodes. The ligand L2H 4 with four carboxylate groups produces a 3D triply interpenetrating structure with the topology net symbol dmd: sqc528, and represents the first reported coordination polymer with this uncommon topology. The Co(II) ions in the crown are not connecting nodes in this structure. The coordination nodes are the tetrahedral Co(II) atoms that link several ligands through their carboxylate groups. The presence of two carboxylates on either side of the ligand appears to facilitate 3D connectivity. Both CPs 1 and 2 show weak antiferromagnetic coupling between their cobalt centers. This research demonstrates that crown ether based carboxylate ligands are effective platforms that can be employed to position a metal ion within the center of an organic linker. They are also effective in generating multidimensional structures with topologies that are novel to coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two novel cobalt coordination polymers 1 and 2 are synthesized based on the use of newly designed ligands L1H  2  and L2H  4 , both containing the diaza-12-crown moiety. In both cases, Co(II) ions are coordinated toward the crown-4 moiety and are, therefore, positioned within the center of the ligand. The ligand L1H  2  with two carboxylate groups produces a 2D layered chiral structure of tetragonal sql net topology and with the Co(II) ions serving as the coordination nodes. The ligand L2H  4  with four carboxylate groups produces a 3D triply interpenetrating structure with the topology net symbol dmd: sqc528, and represents the first reported coordination polymer with this uncommon topology. The Co(II) ions in the crown are not connecting nodes in this structure. The coordination nodes are the tetrahedral Co(II) atoms that link several ligands through their carboxylate groups. The presence of two carboxylates on either side of the ligand appears to facilitate 3D connectivity. Both CPs 1 and 2 show weak antiferromagnetic coupling between their cobalt centers. This research demonstrates that crown ether based carboxylate ligands are effective platforms that can be employed to position a metal ion within the center of an organic linker. They are also effective in generating multidimensional structures with topologies that are novel to coordination polymers.

Found: C, 66.06; H, 7.10; N, 5.84. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 2.6-3.2 (8H, m, OCH2C H  2N), 3.5-3.8 (8H, m, OC H  2CH2N), 3.61(4H, s, NC H  2Ar), 3.87 (6H, s, OC H  3), 7.39 (2H, t, J = 7.2 Hz, Ar H ), 7.69 (2H, br, Ar H ), 7.91 (2H, d, J = 7.2 Hz, Ar H ), 8.04 (2H, s, Ar H ). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 52.33(O C H3), 54.23(N C H2CH2O), 59.86 (NC H  2Ar), 68.66(O C H2CH2N), 128.70(Ar C  5), 128.89(Ar C  4), 130.48(Ar C  2), 130.67(Ar C  6), 133.53(Ar C  3), 134.37(Ar C  1-CH2N),167.12( C O2).

3,3'-((1,7-Dioxa-4,10-diazacyclododecane-4,10-diyl)bis(methylene)) dibenzoic acid, A1 (0.2303 g, 0.489 mmol), was reacted with HCl (aq. 6 N, 2.56 mL) at 90 °C for 6 h with stirring (Scheme S1, ). The white crystals were collected and then recrystallized in water, filtered, and dried in air at ambient temperature for 1 day to produce L1H  2  (0.1897 g, yield 87.6%). Elem. Anal. Calcd.⋅C24H30N2O6⋅2HCl⋅2H2O (fw 551.46) %: C, 52.27; H, 6.58; N, 5.08. Found: C, 51.85; H, 6.50; N, 5.00. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O): 3.33-3.53 (4H, m), 3.54-3.70 (4H, m), 3.70-3.81 (4H, m), 3.81-3.93 (4H, m), 4.60 (4H, s, ArC H  2N), 7.68 (2H, t, J = 8.0 Hz, Ar H  5), 7.86 (2H, d, J = 8.0 Hz, Ar H  4), 8.18 (2H, d, J = 8.0 Hz, Ar H  6), 8.20 (2H, s, ArH2). 13C NMR (100 MHz, D2O): 53.3 (N C H2CH2O), 59.8 (N C H2Ar), 64.0 (NCH2  C H2O), 128.1 (Ar C  5), 129.7 (Ar C  6), 131.1 (Ar C  1 of ArCOOH), 131.6 (Ar C  2), 133.1 (Ar C  4), 136.9 (Ar C  3), 169.9 ( C O2H). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): 3.01-3.23 (4H, m), 3.39-3.53 (4H, m), 3.53-3.68 (4H, m), 3.68-3.84 (4H, m), 4.56 (s, 4H, ArC H  2N), 7.60 (2H, t, J = 7.8 Hz, Ar H  5), 8.03 (2H, d, J = 7.8 Hz, Ar H  4), 8.17 (2H, d, J = 7.8 Hz, Ar H  6), 8.34 (2H, s, Ar H  2), 10.37 (2H, COO H ). 13C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d 6): 52.82 (N C H2CH2O), 59.11 (N C H2-Ar), 64.39 (NCH2  C H2O), 128.94 (Ar C  5), 129.65 (Ar C  6), 130.53 (Ar C  1 of ArCOOH), 131.32 (Ar C  2), 133.6 (Ar C  4), 137.23 (Ar C  3), 166.88 ( C OOH). Synthesis of Ligand L2H4  

Synthesis of Diethyl 5-(chloromethyl)isophthalate (B)

Thionyl chloride (SOCl2, 5 mL) was added to diethyl 5-(hydromethyl)isophthalate (7.18 mmol, 1.811 g) at 0 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Scheme S2, ). The mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 2 h and at ambient temperature for 2 days. Removal of excess SOCl2 under reduced pressure gave a white solid when cooled to ambient temperature. The residue was dissolved in dichloromethane (50 mL) and washed with aq. NaOH (0.1 M) and brine, and solvents were removed under reduced pressure to give diethyl-5-(chloromethyl)isophthalate. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 1.42 (6H, t, J = 7.2 Hz, CH 3), 4.42 (4H, q, J = 7.2 Hz, CH 2CH3), 4.66 (2H, s, CH 2Cl), 8.25 (2H, d, J = 1.2 Hz), 8.63 (1H, t, J = 1.2 Hz). 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ: 14.45, 45.06, 61.68, 130.65, 131.72, 133.78, 138.47, 165.46.

Tetraethyl 5,5'-((1,7-Dioxa-4,10-diazacyclododecane-4,10-diyl)bis(methylene)) Diisophthalate (D) (Scheme S2, )

Diethyl-5-chloromethyl-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (B) (0.0217 g, 0.08 mmol) and potassium carbonate (0.1935 g) were added to a solution of 1,7-diaza-12-crown-4 (0.04 mmol, 0.00697 g) in acetonitrile (2.6 mL) with stirring over 1-2 min. The mixture was heated at 80 °C with stirring for 5 days and cooled to ambient temperature. The solid was filtered out, and the filtrate was concentrated. Crystallization of the filtrate in acetonitrile produced yellow crystals (D) (21 mg, yield 82%). 1HNMR (CDCl3) δ: 1.39 (12H, t, J = 7.1 Hz, OCH2CH 3), 2.79 (8H, s, br, NCH 2CH2O), 3.66 (8H, s, br, NCH2CH 2O), 3.77 (4H, s, br, NCH 2Ar), 4.38 (4H, q, J = 7.1 Hz, OCH 2CH3), 8.28 (4H, s, ArH 2,6), 8.55 (4H, s, ArH 4). 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ: 14.49 (OCH2 CH3), 55.39 (NCH2CH2O), 60.28 (NCH2Ar), 61.42 (OCH2CH3), 69.35 (NCH2 CH2O), 129.54 (C Ar3,5-COOEt), 131.05 (CAr4-H), 132.01 (C Ar1-CH2), 134.32 (C Ar2,6-H), 166.04 (CO2Et). Elem. Anal. Calcd. C34H46N2O10 (wt %): C, 63.54; H, 7.21; N, 4.36. Found: C, 63.25; H, 7.21; N, 4.40.

5,5'-((1,7-Dioxa-4,10-diazacyclododecane-4,10-diyl)bis(methylene))diisophthalic Acid (L2H  4 )

A mixture of D (36 mg) and aq. hydrochloric acid (6 M, 1 mL) was heated at 85-95 °C with stirring for 1 day and cooled to ambient temperature (Scheme S2, ). The solid was collected and rinsed with water to give white crystals of L2H  4  (C26H30N2O10⋅2HCl⋅3H2O). 1HNMR (D2O): 3.50 (6H, m, br), 3.65 (6H, m, br), 3.75-4.01 (8H, m), 8.40 (4H, s), 8.74 (2H, s). 13CNMR (D2O,78 °C) δ: 54.58 (NCH2CH2O), 60.52 (NCH2Ar), 64.92 (NCH2 CH2O), 130.06 (Ar C  3,5-COOH), 130.08 (Ar C  4), 133.45 (Ar C  1-CH2), 137.56 (Ar C  2,6), 169.42 (COOH). IR (cm-1): 1692(s), 1602(w), 1463(w), 1446(w), 1411(w), 1281(m), 1238(m), 1199(m), 1130(s), 980(w), 911(w), 8819(w), 758(w). Elem. Anal. Calcd. (wt %): C, 47.50; H, 5.83; N, 4.26. Found: C, 47.82; H, 5.90; N, 4.25.

Synthesis of Coordination Polymer 1 

A mixture of ligand L1H  2  (2 × 10-6 mol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (6 × 10-6 mol, 1.75 mg), H2O (0.60 mL), and pyridine (2 × 10-3 mL) in a glass vial of 2 mL was capped and heated at 85 °C for 7 day and then cooled to ambient temperature. The red crystals were collected and washed to give 1, with formula C24H28N2O6Co⋅3H2O. IR (cm-1): 1622(m), 1611(m), 1595(w), 1572(m), 1431(w), 1369(s), 1346(s), 1286(w), 1267(w), 1254(w), 1211(w), 1151(w), 1106(m), 1086(m), 1074(m), 1040(w), 1025(w), 984(w), 970(w), 943(w), 912(w), 896(w), 853(w), 836(w), 800 (w), 769(m), 742(m), 715(w), 669(m), 580(w), 556(w), 530(w), 488(w), 469(w), 420(m). Elem. Anal. Calcd. (wt %): C, 55.71; H, 5.84; N, 5.14. Found: C, 55.79; H, 5.74; N, 5.46.

Synthesis of Coordination Polymer 2 

A mixture of ligand L2H  4 , (5 × 10-7 mol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1.5 × 10-6 mol), and pyridine (2 μL) in water (0.5 mL) was sealed in a glass vial of 2 mL and heated at 85 °C for 6 days to produce dark purple crystals of 2 with the formula C26H38Co2N2O16. IR (cm-1): 1613(m), 1566(m), 1372(s), 1342(s), 1226(m), 1092(m), 779(w), 715(s). Elem. Anal. Calcd. (wt %): C, 41.50; H, 5.09; N, 3.72. Found: C, 41.61; H, 5.14; N, 3.76. It was found that the same product was obtained under different temperature conditions (85, 140, and 170 °C).

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis of 1 in air shows a weight loss event of 3.48% from room temperature to 374 °C, corresponding to one molecule of water (Figure a). This was followed by a second weight loss event of 81.3% between 374 and 417 °C, corresponding to degradation of the ligand (expected 82.5%). The residue of 16.7% beyond 417 °C is assigned to the cobalt oxide residue.

The thermogravimetric analysis curve of 2 shows a gradual weight loss of 4.90% up to 210 °C (Figure b), which corresponds to the removal of two uncoordinated water molecules per unit formula (calculated 4.8 wt %). The structure remained stable up to 320 °C, at which two rapid and close weight loss events occurred. The first was 9.6 wt %, corresponding to the loss of two coordinated water molecules. The second weight loss of 71.2% corresponded to the decomposition of the structure (calculated 68.4 wt %). The remaining 21.9 wt % is assigned to the cobalt oxide residue (calculated 19.9 wt %).

Magnetic Susceptibility

The magnetic properties of 1 were investigated in the range of 5–300 K. Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were measured down to 5 K, and χM T values versus temperature are plotted in Figure a, where χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility per molecular unit. The temperature-dependent susceptibility curve shows that the χM T value decreases gradually with temperature, from ∼5.1 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K to 3.5 cm3 mol–1 K at 25 K, and can be considered obeying the Curie–Weiss law with the Curie constant, C, of about 4 cm3 mol–1 K. The small, but abrupt, decrease of χM T below 24 K is attributed to weak antiferromagnetic coupling between cobalt centers.

The magnetic properties of 2 were also investigated in the range of 5–300 K. The temperature-dependent susceptibility curve shows that the χM T value decreases gradually with temperature, from 15.1 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K to 6.0 cm3 mol–1 K at 120 K (Figure b). The graph profile is similar to that of compound 1. It is typical of independent paramagnetic cobalt ions. The abrupt decrease of χM T below 10 K is attributed to weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The high value of χM T at room temperature is larger than the expected spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 mol–1 K for two noninteracting Co(II) with spin S = 3/2 and is attributed to spin–orbit coupling. The temperature-dependent change in Curie constant, especially for compound 2, suggests some possible electron transition on metal centers with changing temperature. Surely, it is fundamentally very interesting, and detailed studies should be further conducted.
